data.text: 11 or 12 Speed Drivetrain for Bike Packing?
11 or 12 speed drivetrain for bike packing?
Singlespeed
data.author: Daniel Dziku Zalewski

data.text: 2x11
data.author: Jens Schlimbach

data.text: 10 speed
data.author: Ashley Burton

data.text: Sounds like 10 or 11 gears too many to me.
data.author: Barry Davis

data.text: bloody fixies
data.author: John Findlay

data.text: it depends on the terrain and your leg muscle power.
data.author: Gediminas Brazaitis

data.text: I live in CO. Plenty of climbs, but would love to leave gear at campsite and do a singletrack once in a while :)
data.author: Surly Wojtek

data.text: I'd go for 11sp, because the chains are cheaper to replace and you can also get a 11-51 cassette to tackle all the possible mountains.
data.author: Gediminas Brazaitis

data.text: In this case more is more
data.author: Andy McGinn

data.text: I'd be more worried about the spread if you're 1x. 11-50 11sp 32 front gets me where I need to go but just depends on how much climbing
data.author: Michael O'Hara

data.text: Yes, why not?
data.author: Maxime Le Plombier

data.text: 10 or 11 speed... Chains\cassettes last a LOT longer and parts are easier to find. 1 or 2x is up to you but consider where you'll be riding, how much weight you'll be dragging along and what kind of shape you're in...
data.author: Jeff Clemons

data.text: I’d rather run 3x8. Easy to replace parts. Maybe switchable to friction shift if something gets tweaked.
data.author: Joe Jeffery

data.text: 3*9
data.author: Andrés Bello

data.text: 8 is all that is needed with a triple Crankset
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: 3x8 or 3x9. 1x12 and 1x1q has very tight tolerances.
data.author: Duncan Pringle

data.text: think mud and touring on 11 speed And it all hams up Fun? No!
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: 2x10 or 1x12.
data.author: Adie Mitchell

data.text: I am told 10 is easier to maintain
data.author: Alan Cole

data.text: I ride a friction 2x10. Its all preference, IMO.
data.author: Kenneth Jarndyce

data.text: If you're buying, go 12.
data.author: Alex Gray

data.text: Whatever your bike has!!
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: I've done SS. I think ideally a 1x geared to the right cassette ratios makes the best sense. # of gears is not as important as the right tooth count.
data.author: Ben Snyder

data.text: I run 1x12 (11-51T) it gives me all the range i need. I have previously bikepacked with 1 x 9 with a terrible range and still made it by.
data.author: Callum Walls

data.text: Makes zero difference. I did Ride Across Wisconsin on a 2x9 Shimano Tiagra. GO RIDE YOUR BIKE!
data.author: Forrest Morrisey

data.text: I’m running Shimano GRX rx400 which is a 2x10 and it seems pretty good. Granny gears for hauling my ass up decent hills and fairly tough. Compared to my old Sora is a massive difference and feels just as good as my 105 if not better.
data.author: Liam Hills

data.text: GRX 812 rear mech (11sp) can do 11-42 rear cassette WITHOUT CHEATING. Save the weight of 2x, and the cost of x12, and get yourself a buttery smooth shifting 1x11 with 400% range. It's the sweet spot right now. Here's a pic of an 812 on my steel cyclocross build. That's an 11-42 XT cassette. No tanpans, no goat links. Hydro or cable. Who cares about the distance between gears more than the total spread? Not me. Who doesn't have an Ultegra 6800 brifter in a drawer somewhere anyway?
data.author: Greg Johnson

data.text: I’m rocking a GRX 11-42. Weird in that I’m rocking a sram cassette, chain, and crankset. But it works great. For bikepacking I swap my 46t chainring for a 38t.
data.author: Josh Govier

data.text: Id say whatever you can get your hands on, range would be the bigger focus, atleast a 10tooth difference between your front chainring and your largest cog in the rear, 32/42, 36/46, 38/50, 40/50, 42/52. 2nd focus would be cadence, whatever chainring and cassette combo that allows you to be in a comfortable cadence, I like to be in the 90 rpm range, when tired Ill drop down into the 80s
data.author: Luis A Vega

data.text: I'm partial to the C 1:12 and P 1:12 Pinion transmissions, the 600% range is excellent, and virtually silent when combined with a Gates Carbon Drive. Picture taken yesterday morning while bikepacking in the Canadian Rockies.
data.author: Guy Stuart

data.text: Who cares? Bike pack on what you have
data.author: John Climber

data.text: 12 GRX or 13 Ekar
data.author: Saj Falcon

data.text: Sram gx 1x 12sp 11-52
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: GRX is still 11 speed so 11
data.author: Chad Braunbeck

data.text: Imma go 12 with 38t chainring.
data.author: Mateo Martinez

data.text: 2 x 11...
data.author: M Guy Santiago

data.text: “Run what you brung” as the saying goes. In other words, don’t worry too much about it.
data.author: Mark Courtenay

data.text: Well, what are you running on the front and what's the tour? 1x? So many variables to consider.
data.author: Mark Hall

data.text: 10
data.author: Tim Silvester

data.text: 2x10 ;)
data.author: Jakub Neburka

data.text: My xt 1x11 rig. Flawless with that 46t cassette.
data.author: Tom Cockerton

data.text: Depends on purpose for the range you require... But in principle are the 11 an 12 speed options smaller bakdes and chains etc... Thus larger wear. More often maintenance. Not per se a disadvantage, but that really depends on yourself. But from that perspective, 10 speed is cheaper replacement and longer life times. But then again, what type of bike is used, what options do you have at the front (1x, 2x,3x...). Where are you going to ride it, mountains or flat, tarmac or gravel or full pull off road.... Etc etc.
data.author: Mark Veenstra

data.text: 1x11, much cheaper.
data.author: Frank Van Wiele

data.text: 2x11
data.author: Robert Young

data.text: 11sp, all of my bikes are on 11sp so no problems scavenging bits for whatever. MTBs on 1x11, road and gravel on 2x11
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: 8
data.author: Scott R Chamberlain

data.text: Amann to AQUABA on Bike ONE crazy expedition where we braved the rain wind snow and cold. Latitudes are getting high! !
data.author: Alain Roea

data.text: What do you Own?
data.author: Chris Danaceau

data.text: Or 9 or 10 or even just 1.
data.author: David Obi Jr.

data.text: If the ratio is the same, there is no difference between an 11 or 12 speed accept an extra gear somewhere in the middle. If you're high is the same and your low is the same, irrelevant
data.author: Logan Moore

data.text: not if there is a huge jump between gears mixed in there.
data.author: Alex Helling

data.text: 10. Maybe 2x10.
data.author: Phil Barnidge

data.text: 3x10 ... still best ever four touring ...
data.author: Andreas Syma

data.text: Doesn't really matter, initially had 1x11 on my bike and I want drop bars, so I stick to it. Each of those has pros and cons when it comes to handlebars, shifters, availability of wide range cassettes, prices etc. And for bikepacking there's no need for better cadence control, so no urgent need for 12 if we have 11.
data.author: Marcin Sowiński

data.text: 2x10.
data.author: Gerard Castellà

data.text: I upgraded from 2*10 to 1*12. While I do enjoy the simplicity, if I had my time again, I think 2*11 gives the best options for range, durability and replacement cost.
data.author: Steve Coombs

data.text: mine is 1x12, 32 with a 51-10
data.author: Danya Anderson

data.text: The number of gears is less important than getting the right range. But I’d rather have 12 than 11.
data.author: Nathan Morey

data.text: 2x10 with 11-42 cassette for hills and lots of gear. 1x11 11-42 for ultralight fast riding
data.author: Marius Marcus Tamosiunas

data.text: Eagel 1x12 is just amaizing!
data.author: Tom Jostes

data.text: Except you can spin out on the flat .
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: I personally go with the best gear inches on the lowest gear. For me that’s the most important thing.
data.author: Micah Deffries

data.text: I would be worried on the Rattio, hilly 1×11 ( 12-38) etc, flats singlespeed 😁
data.author: Edwin Andrew Diaz
